title: Cloud Concentration Risk
context: Organizations migrate to cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP) for agility, scalability, and cost efficiency. The migration works. Then dependency deepens. Proprietary services, managed databases, serverless functions, and cloud-native tooling create lock-in that makes switching providers a multi-year, multi-million dollar project. When the provider has an outage, your business has an outage. When they raise prices, you pay. The cloud promised freedom from infrastructure. It delivered a different kind of dependency.
hypothesis: Cloud migration reduces infrastructure risk and cost while increasing operational flexibility.

chain.root: Migrate infrastructure to a single cloud provider

effects.label: Teams adopt provider-specific services for speed
effects.impact: 70-80% of workloads use proprietary services within 3 years

children.label: Lambda/Cloud Functions, DynamoDB, Cosmos DB — no portable equivalents
IAM, networking, and monitoring deeply coupled to provider
Engineers develop provider-specific skills, not portable cloud skills

effects.label: Switching costs become prohibitive
effects.impact: Migration estimated at 2-4 years and $5-50M for mid-size companies

children.label: Provider knows you can't leave — pricing leverage shifts permanently
Annual price increases of 5-15% become non-negotiable
Contract negotiations become adversarial — you have no BATNA

effects.label: Single points of failure at provider level
effects.impact: Major outages affect thousands of companies simultaneously

children.label: us-east-1 outage takes down half the internet
Your DR plan assumes the provider works — it doesn't protect against provider failure
Correlated failure: your app, your monitoring, your alerting all go down together

effects.label: Cloud costs grow faster than revenue
effects.impact: Cloud spend grows 20-30% annually vs 10-15% revenue growth

children.label: Repatriation becomes attractive but lock-in makes it nearly impossible
FinOps teams created to manage costs — adding headcount to save on infrastructure

dontIf: Your business cannot tolerate any single provider having outage-level control over your operations
Your cloud spend already exceeds 20% of revenue and is growing faster
ifYouMust: Use portable abstractions (Kubernetes, Terraform, PostgreSQL) over proprietary services where possible
Maintain a cloud exit plan — document what it would take to migrate, even if you never do
Negotiate multi-year contracts with price caps and egress fee waivers
Run critical workloads across at least two availability zones, ideally two regions

alternatives.name: Multi-cloud strategy
alternatives.note: Distribute workloads across providers — higher complexity but lower concentration risk

alternatives.name: Hybrid cloud
alternatives.note: Keep sensitive or high-volume workloads on-premise, use cloud for burst and non-critical

alternatives.name: Cloud-agnostic stack
alternatives.note: Kubernetes + Terraform + open-source databases — portable by design, higher initial effort

sources.title: Gartner: Cloud Concentration Risk Report
sources.note: 60% of enterprises identify single-cloud dependency as a top-5 technology risk

sources.title: Andreessen Horowitz: The Cost of Cloud
sources.note: Cloud costs consume 50%+ of revenue for many SaaS companies, repatriation could save 30-50%

sources.title: AWS us-east-1 Outage Post-Mortem (2021)
sources.note: Single region outage cascaded across thousands of companies including major SaaS providers

sources.title: Flexera State of the Cloud Report 2024
sources.note: Cloud waste estimated at 28% of total spend, cost management is top cloud challenge

falsifiability: Companies with single-cloud strategies show lower total infrastructure costs than multi-cloud or hybrid approaches over 5 years
Major cloud provider outages affect fewer than 1% of dependent companies' operations
Cloud provider pricing remains stable or decreases for locked-in customers over 5-year contract periods

seo.description: Single-cloud dependency locks in 70-80% of workloads on proprietary services, making switching a $5-50M multi-year project. Costs grow 2x faster than projected while outage risk correlates.
keywords: cloud concentration risk second order effects
